question: Which organization is Anne Linnet a member of?

content.source_1:
Title: The Harmony of Rebellion: Anne Linnet and Shit & Chanel's Enduring Legacy

In the vibrant music scene of 1970s Denmark, a revolutionary sound emerged, shattering conventions and defying norms. At the heart of this movement was Anne Linnet, a trailblazing musician who would leave an indelible mark on the industry. As a key member of the provocative band Shit & Chanel, Linnet's contributions would forever change the landscape of Danish music. The year was 1974, and Copenhagen was abuzz with creative energy. Anne Linnet, a talented singer-songwriter, had already made a name for herself in the local music circuit. Her unique voice, a mesmerizing blend of sweet melodies and raw emotion, had captured the attention of fans and critics alike. It was during this time that Linnet crossed paths with a group of like-minded musicians, united by their desire to push the boundaries of traditional music. Shit & Chanel, a band born from the ashes of rebellion, was the brainchild of Linnet and her collaborators. The group's name, a deliberate provocation, reflected their commitment to challenging the status quo. With Linnet at the helm, Shit & Chanel's music became a powerful fusion of punk, rock, and pop, infused with a healthy dose of feminist attitude. One of the band's earliest recordings, "Tak for sidst" (Thanks for Last Time), released in 1975, showcased Linnet's distinctive vocals and poignant songwriting. The song's themes of love, freedom, and empowerment resonated deeply with a generation of young Danes, who saw themselves reflected in the band's unapologetic lyrics. As Shit & Chanel's popularity grew, so did their influence. They became a staple of the Danish music scene, known for their electrifying live performances and unbridled energy. Linnet's stage presence, a potent mix of charisma and vulnerability, captivated audiences and inspired a new wave of female musicians. The band's 1976 album, "Shit & Chanel," solidified their position as one of Denmark's most innovative and daring acts. The album's lead single, "Du er ikke kvinde nok" (You're Not Woman Enough), featuring Linnet's soaring vocals, became an anthem for feminist activism in Denmark. Throughout the late 1970s and early 1980s, Shit & Chanel continued to produce music that was both provocative and profound.
content.source_2: As Anne Linnet stepped off the plane in Yerevan, the crisp Armenian air enveloped her like a warm hug. She had always been drawn to the rich cultural heritage of this ancient land, and the opportunity to perform at the prestigious Yerevan Jazz Festival was a dream come true. But little did the audience know, Anne's connection to Armenia went far beyond her love of music. As she made her way to her hotel, Anne's mind wandered back to her last visit, when she had stumbled upon a dusty, forgotten corner of the National Library. It was there that she had discovered an obscure manuscript, penned by a 19th-century Armenian composer, that would change the course of her music forever. The intricate melodies and haunting harmonies had spoken directly to her soul, and she had spent countless hours pouring over the pages, transcribing the notes into her own compositions. It was on that same trip that Anne had met Dr. Hovhannisyan, a renowned musicologist and member of the National Academy of Sciences of Armenia. Over steaming cups of coffee, they had discussed the intersection of music and mathematics, and Anne had been struck by the professor's passion and expertise. As their conversation drew to a close, Dr. Hovhannisyan had extended an unexpected invitation: to join the Academy as an honorary member, in recognition of her contributions to the field of music. Anne's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of her hotel room door opening. Her manager, Lars, bustled in, carrying a bouquet of fresh flowers and a stack of festival programs. "Anne, darling, you're going to knock their socks off tonight!" he exclaimed, as he began to prep her for the evening's performance. But Anne's mind was still in the National Library, surrounded by the dusty tomes and forgotten manuscripts.
